Mitchell's idea sounds good as well for the TTT-memory domain.  But 
I guess you still need a stopping criterion in case the network 
never says it's ready.  Also, the complexity of representing what it 
means to be "ready" may be almost as difficult to discover as the 
solution itself, in which case its value would be questionable.  But 
I don't know that to be the case so it's definitely worth trying.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "zenguyuno" <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Robert Winkel" <robert_winkel@h...> 
> wrote:
> <snip>
> 
> > If I don't stabilize, should I at least activate the network a 
set
> > number of times?  If I only activate the network once, then
> > the mapping of current input to current output can only be
> > very simple.  What I am thinking is that I pick a number of
> > activations that corresponds to the approximate memory
> > size that I am after, so that if I would like the network to
> > remember the last 5 states, then I will relax the network by
> > activating it 5 times for each input.  What's your opinion on
> > this?
> 
> I really think I have the answer you need, which is to let the 
> network tell you when its done "thinking".   You do this by having 
> one additional output which is designated as a "ready" line.
> 
> You start with all outputs at zero.  As soon as the "ready" output 
is 
> high, then you are done, and you take all of the other outputs as 
> your result.  High could be defined as > .5.  I think this is a 
> general approach that applies to many problems.  Essentially, you 
are 
> letting the nework tell you when it is done processing.  I have 
used 
> this approach in two programs, and it worked perfectly.
> 
> Mitchell Timin 
> http:\\annevolve.sourceforge.net
